CN.content:
Please identify the "Material Name" entities in the following paragraph. Please present the valid entities as a Markdown table with one column "Material Name". Make sure to present the entities precisely in the same words as in the original paragraph.

Paragraph: The hole mobility ( μ hole = 4.68 × 10^-5 cm^2 / V°s ) obtained with the thermally annealed film is one order higher than that without post annealing ( μ hole = 4.02 × 10^-6 cm^2 / V°s ) , whereas in the both cases , the electron mobilities ( μ electron ) are similar ( 1.24 × 10^-3 and 5.58 × 10^-3 cm^2 / V°s ) for as-cast and annealed films , respectively , yielding a smaller difference between the mobility ratio for the annealed film.

Let's think step by step.

| Material Name |
| --- |
| thermally annealed film |
| film without post annealing |
| as-cast film |
| annealed film |

The paragraph is discussing the mobility of two types of films - one that has been thermally annealed and another that has not been annealed or has undergone post-annealing. The material names are explicitly mentioned as "film without post annealing" and "thermally annealed film." Additionally, the paragraph mentions "as-cast film" and "annealed film" in relation to the electron mobilities, which are material properties of the films.

Please remove entities that do not clearly refer to "Material name" and present the valid entities as a Markdown table with one column "Material Name".

Make sure to present the entities precisely in the same words as in the original paragraph.

| Material Name |
| --- |
| film without post annealing |
| thermally annealed film |
| as-cast film |
| annealed film |

The paragraph discusses the hole mobility of two types of films - one that has not undergone post-annealing and another that has been thermally annealed. The material names are explicitly mentioned as "film without post annealing" and "thermally annealed film." Additionally, the paragraph mentions "as-cast film" and "annealed film" in relation to the electron mobilities, which are material properties of the films. The specific material names for the films with different electron mobilities are not explicitly stated in the paragraph, but it can be inferred that they refer to the same films as the hole mobility measurements - "as-cast film" and "annealed film."

Paragraph: The hole mobility ( μ hole = 4.68 × 10^-5 cm^2 / V°s ) obtained with the thermally annealed film is one order higher than that without post annealing ( μ hole = 4.02 × 10^-6 cm^2 / V°s ) , whereas in the both cases , the electron mobilities ( μ electron ) are similar ( 1.24 × 10^-3 and 5.58 × 10^-3 cm^2 / V°s ) for as-cast and annealed films , respectively , yielding a smaller difference between the mobility ratio for the annealed film.

Let's think step by step.

| Property Name |
| ------------- |
| hole mobility (without post annealing) (μ hole = 4.02 × 10^-6 cm^2 / V°s) |
| hole mobility (with thermally annealed film) (μ hole = 4.68 × 10^-5 cm^2 / V°s) |
| electron mobility (as-cast film) (μ electron = 1.24 × 10^-3 cm^2 / V°s) |
| electron mobility (annealed film) (μ electron = 5.58 × 10^-3 cm^2 / V°s |
| mobility ratio (for as-cast film) |
| mobility ratio (for annealed film)

Please remove entities that do not clearly refer to "Material property" and present the valid entities as a Markdown table with one column "Property Name".

Make sure to present the entities precisely in the same words as in the original paragraph.

| Property Name |
| ------------- |
| hole mobility (without post annealing) (μ hole = 4.02 × 10^-6 cm^2 / V°s) |
| hole mobility (with thermally annealed film) (μ hole = 4.68 × 10^-5 cm^2 / V°s) |
| electron mobility (annealed film) (μ electron = 5.58 × 10^-3 cm^2 / V°s) |
| mobility ratio (for annealed film) |

The entities "hole mobility (as-cast film)" and "electron mobility (as-cast film)" are removed as they are already mentioned in the previous row as "electron mobilities" with respective values for as-cast and annealed films. The term "obtained" and "yielding" are also removed as they do not clearly refer to material properties.
